conclusion: Determine the potential difference between points a and b on the circular ring as it moves through a uniform magnetic field.
Potential difference is induced due to the motion of the ring in the magnetic field, analyzed using Faraday's law and motional emf.
Circular ring of radius R moving with constant velocity v into a region with uniform magnetic field B.
Magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the ring (into the page, indicated by crosses).
Angle ∠aOb = 90° implies arc ab subtends a right angle at the center of the circle.
Concept of motional EMF: When a conductor moves through a magnetic field, an emf is induced across it.
Motional emf formula: emf = B ⋅ v ⋅ L, where L is the length of the conductor perpendicular to the direction of motion and within the magnetic field.
Determine effective length L: Arc ab is a quarter of the circle, effective length L is the chord of the circle subtending a 90° angle at the center.
Calculate chord length ab using formula for chord length in a circle: L = R √2.
Calculate induced EMF: Substitute values into motional emf formula, emf = B ⋅ v ⋅ R √2.
Induced emf is equivalent to the potential difference between points a and b because the ring is a closed loop and emf acts along arc ab.
Final answer: Potential difference between points a and b is V_ab = B ⋅ v ⋅ R √2.
